position.marginalia_text: Acerrimi iudicij quasi Corpus, Ca[e]sar: Vmbra[e], Sallustrius, et Virgilius.

marginalia.translation: Caesar is practically a body of most penetrating judgment; Sallust and Virgil are shadows.
Nothing vain in the three most prudent things.
No verbose word in those things.

position.marginalia_text: Percurrendi ( dignissimi: semper redeundu[m] ad iudicium / Ca[e]saris, Salustij, Virgilij: quorum vena aurum purissimum.

marginalia.translation: The most dignified men must be perused. One must always return to the judgment of Caesar, Sallust, and Virgil, who have a purest gold in their vein.

position.marginalia_text: Maximum mundi Paradoxu[m], Cardani Encomiu[m] Neronis: egregius discursus pragmaticus.

marginalia.translation: The greatest paradox of the world, Girolamo Cardano's 'Encomium Neronis': an extraordinary pragmatic discourse.

position.marginalia_text: Excellunt iudicio Ca[e]sar, Sallustius, Virgilius: qui soli possunt prudentissimu[m] viru[m] efficere: pra[e]sertim cum Ciceronis Officijs: de administranda prouincia: de petitione Consulatus. Pragmaticum etiam astutissimu[m] Tacitus, Gandinus, Durandus.
Pra[e]sertim cu[m] Mithridatis epistola, et concione contra Romanos: =

= Aristotelis politicis, Oeconomicisq[ue] technis: Xenophontis Tyranno: Dionis apistia: Plutarchi politicis: Jouis Elogio Ca[e]saris Borgia[e]: Catharina[e] Medicea[e] practicis: [p. 142: Equitis Poncetti discursu aulico de Principijs imperij Turcici: Ritratti di Guicciardini: Phalardis tyranni Epistolis: Mahometis 2. epistolis.]

marginalia.translation: Caesar, Sallust, and Virgil excel in judgement, they alone who can create the most prudent man: especially with Cicero's 'On duties', 'On administering an office', 'On running for the consulship'. Also Tactitus, Gandinus, and Durandus [can create] a most astute pragmatist. Especially with Mithridatis' letter and with his speech against the Romans: and with Aristotle's economic and political artifices: with Xenophon's 'Hiero', Dio Chrysostom's 'Diffidence', Plutarch's political 'Opuscula', with the Giovio's' eulogy of Cesare Borgia, with the practices of Catherine de' Medici: [p. 142: With the golden discourse of Maurice Poncet, a knight, 'on the rulers of the Turkish empire', Francesco Guicciardini's 'Ritratti', 'In Phalaridis tyranni agrigentini Epistolas', with the 'letters of Mehmed 2'.]
